title: Getting Started with Git and GitHub in RStudio
text:
The Challenge
As data analysts, we produce a lot of files

code
figures
tables
reports

Organising these files is an important, albeit often unglamorous, part of our job.

title: Getting Started with Git and GitHub in RStudio
text:
The Challenge


Managing versions What do you do with old code?
Ensuring reproducibility Can others reproduce your results? What about your future self?
Facilitating collaboration Can other team members easily contribute?

title: Getting Started with Git and GitHub in RStudio
text:
The old school solution üõµ
The old school solution combines many practical strategies:


Using file naming conventions to track different file versions

analysis-16may2025.R
analysis-19may2025-mh.R
analysis-final.R
analysis-final-final.R

Note changes directly in code comments or separate documentation
Use shared folders, google drive etc
Share code and code snippets over email, slack etc

title: Getting Started with Git and GitHub in RStudio
text:
The old school solution üõµ

This is ok(ish) for 1-2 people working on a small project. But if the project is large, involves many people or goes on for a long time this approach very quickly breaks down

title: Getting Started with Git and GitHub in RStudio
text:
The new school solution üöÄ
The new school solution is to use dedicated version control software.
There are a few options out there but by far the most popular choice is the combination of git + GitHub

title: Getting Started with Git and GitHub in RStudio
text:
Via git-scm.com


Git is software for tracking different versions of code files you are working on locally.



Via logos-world.net


GitHub is a cloud-based platform for sharing and collaborating on projects managed with Git

title: Getting Started with Git and GitHub in RStudio
text: Illustrations from the Openscapes blog GitHub for supporting, contributing, and failing safely by Allison Horst and Julia Lowndes.

It seems a bit complicated

Via GIPHY
Is it worth it?

title: Getting Started with Git and GitHub in RStudio
section: Yes!! It is definitely worth it!
text:
Yes!! It is definitely worth it!


Version control | Essential for reproducibility
Collaboration | OpenSAFELY, OHDSI, R package development
Organisation | e.g.¬†Code, data & outputs all stored together
Easy web presence | e.g.¬†any public GitHub repo; these slides!
Great for teaching
Powerful search
Issue tracking | Hyperlink the bug, discussion about the bug & the solution!
It is all free*




*Well, mostly. The free products will cover most academic/research use cases.

title: Getting Started with Git and GitHub in RStudio
text:
Working locally: Git client
To use Git on your computer you need a Git Client. There are heaps of git clients available, with different pros and cons. Here are a few examples:



1. Command line

Terminal (Mac)
Git bash (Windows)
PowerShell (Windows)
RStudio Terminal

title: Getting Started with Git and GitHub in RStudio
text:
Collaboration: Git hosting service
To enable collaboration you need a Git Hosting service. There are heaps of options with different pros and cons, but the core functionality is usually the same.



GitHub

Widely used
Lots of resources

title: Getting Started with Git and GitHub in RStudio
text:
Collaboration: Git hosting service
To enable collaboration you need a Git Hosting service. There are heaps of options with different pros and cons, but the core functionality is usually the same.


Gitea

A light-weight easy to install option.
Implemented in SURE and ERICA.

title: Getting Started with Git and GitHub in RStudio
text:
Collaboration: Git hosting service
To enable collaboration you need a Git Hosting service. There are heaps of options with different pros and cons, but the core functionality is usually the same.


GitLab

Can be hosted on a private server so ideal for sensitive projects.

title: Getting Started with Git and GitHub in RStudio
text:
Key concept: R Projects

We use R projects to keep all our code and files organised in a single space



Artwork by @allison_horst

title: Getting Started with Git and GitHub in RStudio
text:
Mini-Exercise

 3 minutes

Create a new project in RStudio






In the top right-hand corner of Rstudio (i) click the arrow and (ii) choose New Project 
Select New Directory then New Project
Set the directory name to Exercise 1 and choose a sensible subdirectory location (this is where the project will live on your computer)
Tick ‚úÖ Create a Git Repository
Click Create Project

title: Getting Started with Git and GitHub in RStudio

setwd("C:\Users\jenny\path\that\only\I\have")
I will come into your office and SET YOUR COMPUTER ON FIRE üî•.

title: Getting Started with Git and GitHub in RStudio
section: Key concept: Relative paths with here::here()
text:
Key concept: Relative paths with here::here()


Artwork by @allison_horst

title: Getting Started with Git and GitHub in RStudio
text:
Mini-Exercise

 3 minutes

Are you here yet?






Make sure you are working in the R Project you created earlier 
Enter here::here() at the console to see your current working directory. This should be where you saved your project!
Enter here::here(".gitignore") at the console. What happens?
Enter file.exists(here::here(".gitignore")) at the console. This should return TRUE. Note that you don‚Äôt need the full path to locate the file!



Note We will talk more about what the .gitignore file actually does later

title: Getting Started with Git and GitHub in RStudio
text:
Key concept: Repository




A repository is where the magic happens 

Referred to as a repo
1 git project = 1 repo = 1 RStudio Project
Database of changes to your code (aka diffs)
Hidden folder on your system named .git

title: Getting Started with Git and GitHub in RStudio
text:
Key concept: Commit




Commit

A Commit is like clicking save in a MS Word document
It saves a snapshot of the code at that point in time
Why you commit you must write a message explaining what changed
Committing is a two stage process‚Ä¶

title: Getting Started with Git and GitHub in RStudio
text:
Key concept: Staging area
You can only commit files that have been added to the staging area


There are a few advantages to breaking commits into two steps:

You can split a big edit into bite-sized pieces
Easier to review
If you make a mistake you can unstage. You can‚Äôt un-commit!

title: Getting Started with Git and GitHub in RStudio
text:
Mini-Exercise

 3 minutes

Try adding and committing






Task New File Add Commit



Make sure you are working in the R Project you created earlier 
Create and save a new text file named recipe.txt (File > New File > Text File). You should be able to see the new file in the Git panel 
In the Git panel, tick the box next to recipe.txt to add the file to the staging area 
Click the commit icon  to commit the file. Add a sensible message then click Commit

title: Getting Started with Git and GitHub in RStudio
text:
Key concept: The .gitignore file
You can tell git to ignore specific files and folders by listing them in a special file: .gitignore

The default .gitignore file for R projects list files that are specific to your configuration‚Äîthese are personal so we don‚Äôt want to share them.
.Rproj.user
.Rhistory
.RData
.Ruserdata


.gitignore also recognises patterns:

*.xlsx (ignore all xlsx files)
*.Rda (ignore all .Rda files)
/Data (ignore everything in the folder named Data)

title: Getting Started with Git and GitHub in RStudio
text:
Mini-Exercise

 3 minutes

The .gitignore file






Make sure you are working in the R Project you created earlier 
Create and save a new file private.txt (File > New File > Text File). Git should automatically detect the new file so you should see the file appear in the git panel.
Open the .gitignore file and add the text private.txt on a new line. Click save.

Once you ignore the file it is no longer being tracked and it should disappear from the git panel.

title: Getting Started with Git and GitHub in RStudio
text:
What files can I track?

This all works best for non-binary or text files e.g.¬†your typical code files (.sas, .do, .R, .Rmd, .py) but also .png, .csv etc
You can include non-binary files (.pdf, .docx, .xlsx etc) in a git repo but the diff features won‚Äôt work. It can still be useful if using the repo as a central organisation point (e.g.¬†if you save your published manuscript with the analysis code).

title: Getting Started with Git and GitHub in RStudio
text:
How often should I commit?

Well, it depends.
Just like when you start writing a word document you might not click save very often as you spew out lots of ideas, but at the end of your thesis you will carefully save every change!
It is best practice to keep commits fairly small and related, especially for mature projects.

title: Getting Started with Git and GitHub in RStudio
text:
What about my sensitive data/code?



If your data are sensitive be very careful not to track with Git
Private repos are available if you don‚Äôt want the public to see your code (you can change to public later if desired.)
Git Hosting Services like Gitea are available in secure analysis environments (SURE/ERICA etc)

title: Getting Started with Git and GitHub in RStudio
section: How does my repo align with my project folder?
text:
How does my repo align with my project folder?


You need to actively think about this!
Option: Root folder of the project
Option: Specific folder (e.g.¬†just Code/)
Git ignores files and folders listed in the special .gitignore file

title: Getting Started with Git and GitHub in RStudio
section: Next steps for the Medicines Intelligence CRE?
text:
Next steps for the Medicines Intelligence CRE?



Setting up/joining an Organisational GitHub account?
Advocating for Gitea in your secure analysis environment?
Setting up a repo for shared code?
Tracking your next analysis with Git/GitHub?

title: Getting Started with Git and GitHub in RStudio
text:
Any final questions?

Please complete the post-event survey! ‚ù§Ô∏è

title: Getting Started with Git and GitHub in RStudio
text:
Mini-Exercise

 5 minutes

Clone a remote repo
A note on this exercise: In this exercise you will clone a remote repo from GitHub to your local RStudio. The example uses a repo from the tame R package for identifying clusters of medication use based on dose, timing and type of medication published by Anna Laksafoss from the University of Copenhagen. You will use Git‚Äôs powerful search function to find this repo but note you can do this exercise with any repo you like!

title: Getting Started with Git and GitHub in RStudio
text:
Mini-Exercise

 5 minutes

Clone a remote repo






Task GitHub URL Clone



On github.com search Anna Laksafoss and open the tame R package repo 
Within the repo, click on   Code and copy the HTTPS url to your clipboard 
Launch the RStudio New Project Wizard, but this time select Version Control then Git
Paste the HTTPS url into the Repository URL box and specify a sensible subdirectory location for this new repo 
Optionally tick ‚úÖ Open in new session then select Create Project

title: Exercise 3: Branching and pull requests
text: Overview: If you are collaborating with others you will need to get work on local branches to avoid clashes. Here you can practice creating a new branch in RStudio then submitting a Merge Request to GitHub

title: Exercise 3: Branching and pull requests
text:
1.1 Create a new branch
 * In the Git panel, click the New Branch icon to launch this dialogue box * Name the new branch something short and meaningful (no spaces!) * Click Create * Close the pop up

title: Exercise 3: Branching and pull requests
section: 1.2 Create a new file, then add and commit
text:
1.2 Create a new file, then add and commit

Notes

Create and save a new R Script, e.g.¬†extra-analysis.R
Add and commit this file in the usual way
Remember to add a short, meaningful commit message

title: Exercise 3: Branching and pull requests
text:
1.3 Push your branch to GitHub


You can push from either (i) the Git pane or (ii) the commit dialogue box

title: Exercise 3: Branching and pull requests
text:
2.1 Click Compare & Pull Request

Notes

This will create a new pull request
You got this ‚ù§Ô∏è

title: Exercise 3: Branching and pull requests
text:
2.2 Click Create pull request

Notes

You should see the green tick Able to merge
In more complex projects there may be conflicts between user edits, but one step at a time.
Here you could optionally add labels, assign reviewers etc
When you are ready click Create pull request.

title: Exercise 3: Branching and pull requests
text:
2.3 Merge pull request
 Notes

Because there are no conflicts, merging can be performed automatically
When you are ready click Merge pull request then Confirm merge

title: Exercise 3: Branching and pull requests
section: 3.1 Switch back to the main branch
text:
3.1 Switch back to the main branch

Notes

If you left your additional file open in RStudio you might now get a pop-up to say it has been deleted. Don‚Äôt panic, it is just not on the main branch (yet!)



At this point you will have the option to delete your branch in GitHub. You can if you like, but if you think you might make more related changes later you can leave it open.

title: Exercise 3: Branching and pull requests
section: 3.2 Pull the remote changes to your local repo
text:
3.2 Pull the remote changes to your local repo
 Notes

This will pull the changes in the remote branch to your local repo



If you have left your branch open, you can change back if there are more edits needed.


Made it this far? Legend!

title: Exercises overview
text:
In these exercises you will practice three common workflows:

Pushing a repo that exists in RStudio to GitHub
Creating a repo in GitHub and cloning to RStudio
Branching and pull requests




Don‚Äôt worry if you get stuck‚Äîjust shout for help!



Artwork by @allison_horst.




 Back to top

title: Schedule
text:
The Octocat‚Äîan octopus-cat with five appendages‚Äîis the beloved GitHub logo. Read more here.


Schedule






Time
Activity




10:00 - 10:10
Introductions and housekeeping


10:10 - 10:20
Motivation: Why use Git and GitHub


10:20 - 11:10
Working with GitHub in RStudio + Mini Exercises


11:10 - 11:20
Morning tea


11:20 - 12:10
Hands-on exercises


12:10 - 12:30
Questions and discussion










Prerequisites
Thank you for enrolling in the    Git and GitHub in RStudio workshop   
To get the most out of the workshop, please run through the checklist below and make sure you have all the necessary software installed in advance. If you are already working with git in RStudio you may be ready to go already. If you are just getting started, keep in mind that these configuration steps can be half the battle. Don‚Äôt worry if you get stuck, we are here to help.








A note on the key reference



Configuring Git, GitHub and RStudio to work together is half the battle when it comes to using Git in RStudio.
Luckily there is an excellent online reference for this: Happy Git and GitHub for the useR by Jennifer Bryan. The chapters linked below refer to key sections in this book.
We won‚Äôt have time to configure everybody‚Äôs laptop at the workshop so please try to work through these steps in advance! The best strategy is to carefully read the recommended sections in order and follow the directions diligently. But there is a lot of detail to work through so don‚Äôt worry if you get stuck‚Äîreach out for help!




Checklist:
Can you tick every item below?

At least a basic familiarity with R and RStudio. If you are a beginner or want a refresh, check out the one-hour webinar A gengle introduction to tidy statistics in R) 
A free GitHub user account. See Ch 4. Register a GitHub account 
A recent version of R (at least v4.3.0) and RStudio (at least a 2024 version) installed on your laptop. See Ch 5. Install or upgrade R and RStudio 
Git installed on your laptop. See Ch 6. Install Git 
Set up a Personal Access Token (PAT) to allow RStudio to communicate with GitHub. See Ch 9. Personal access token for HTTPS and in particular Section 9.1 TL;DR 









Setting up a Personal Access Token



Follow Section 9.1 TL;DR from Happy Git and GitHub for the useR to set up your Personal Access Token. The easiest way to do this is to run the suggested commands from R. To run these commands you may need to install the usethis and gitcreds packages if they are not installed already. If you get an error message indicating that you don‚Äôt have the packages installed you can install them by entering the commands below at the console.

install.packages("usethis")


install.packages("gitcreds")

As per Section 9.1 TL;DR, the following R commands can be used to set up a Personal Access Token from RStudio.

usethis::create_github_token()


Entering a note to describe the tokens use case is useful for identifying and managing tokens. Choose a note that describes your use case, e.g.¬†RStudio projects.
Set the expiration to 30 days. You can always extend this.
The GitHub PAT scope is like a set of permissions that define what actions the token can perform on your behalf on GitHub. You can use the default scopes of workflow, gist, and user.


gitcreds::gitcreds_set()








 Back to top

title: Exercise 1: Pushing a repo that exists in RStudio to GitHub
text: Overview: You already have a repo named Exercise1 in your local RStudio, in this exercise you will create an empty remote repo in GitHub and link it to your local repo

title: Exercise 1: Pushing a repo that exists in RStudio to GitHub
section: 1.1 Go to github.com, and click the + symbol then New repository
text: 1.1 Go to github.com, and click the + symbol then New repository

title: Exercise 1: Pushing a repo that exists in RStudio to GitHub
section: 1.2 Specify yourself as the owner and name the repo Exercise 1
text:
1.2 Specify yourself as the owner and name the repo Exercise 1

Notes

Optionally add a description for your repo
You can choose Public or Private‚ÄîPublic repos can be viewed online by anyone.
Because you already have a local repo, don‚Äôt add a README file, a .gitignore file, or a license.
When you are ready, click Create Repository.



The remote repo name doesn‚Äôt have to match your local repo or RStudio Project name, but it can be good practice to keep things organised!

title: Exercise 1: Pushing a repo that exists in RStudio to GitHub
section: 1.3 Copy the quick setup code to your clipboard
text: 1.3 Copy the quick setup code to your clipboard

title: Exercise 2: Creating a repo in GitHub and cloning to RStudio
text: Overview: An alternative workflow is to create a remote repo in GitHub and then clone it locally

title: Exercise 2: Creating a repo in GitHub and cloning to RStudio
section: 1.1 Go to github.com and create a new repository
text:
1.1 Go to github.com and create a new repository

Notes

Name the repo Exercise 2
This time click to add a README file and choose the .gitignore template for R
When you are ready, click Create Repo

title: Exercise 2: Creating a repo in GitHub and cloning to RStudio
section: 2.1 Copy the repo HTTPS url to your clipboard
text:
2.1 Copy the repo HTTPS url to your clipboard

Notes

Make sure you are choosing the HTTPS url

title: Exercise 2: Creating a repo in GitHub and cloning to RStudio
section: 2.2 In RStudio, create a new project with this url
text:
2.2 In RStudio, create a new project with this url


Launch the New Project wizard and choose New Project > Version Control Git
Paste in the repository url and name the Project Exercise 2
Tick the box to open the repo in a new session
When you are ready click Create Project



That‚Äôs it, you‚Äôre done! Try adding and saving some new files then practice committing and then pushing. You should be able to see your commit history in GitHub.
